@jmuld1 "We're already past 1.5 degrees rise today, and we are on track for 3 degrees rise (by 2050)." --- 10/11/20 live stream: Antonio Guterres, United Nations Secretary General. I assume Mr. Guterres and the United Nations are relying on the peer-reviewed scientic evidence from scientists in 195 member countries contained in the IPCC reports (International Panel on Climate Change). Earth history has had many climate changes, and resulting mass extinction events caused by global climate changing rapidly (within a few decades). I do know that UN Secretary General Guterres' "we're on track for 3 degrees rise (by 2050)", if based on the UN IPCC report, safe to assume, therefore actually does not take into account the feedback loop of methane release from thawing permafrost. The same amount of methane causes 80x the warming that co2 causes. This a huge omission, therefore, and it puzzles me why the IPCC doesn't include the methane feedback loop, and other feedback loops. Science detects and measures many self-reinforcing feedback loops that are causing more warming. Including all the feedback loops, the science shows that the actual worse case scenario is 6-8 degrees warming (by 2050-2100) ! This warming melts the arctic ice, among other things. The ice-free arctic in the next few years (!) is especially troubling because a warmer arctic causes a disruption and slowing of the jet stream, turning it into an air pattern that is more wavy and less straight. These wavy air currents bring arctic temperatures more south than usual, and allow tropical temperatures more north than usual. The result has been extreme record-breaking heat in Alaska and Siberia, for example, and arctic freezes as far south as the southern United States! These extreme temperatures disrupt the natural growing seasons and cycles, confusing blooming trees, for example, which bloom too early, and then therefore their fruits are wiped out by a late frost. Also entire orchards' trees are dying from new disease and pests in the warmer climate. The slowed jet stream air currents also cause storms to stay longer in a location, pouring more rain there, causing flooding. The slowed jet stream air currents also cause heat waves to stay longer in a location, baking the soil and causing drought. Climate change causes these extreme weather events (and pests, like locusts) to happen more often, and the result is that food crops are killed. The total global food harvest is smaller therefore, which is causing famine. This will get worse as climate change increases, resulting in increasing extremes in weather, and smaller and smaller food supply, and more and more famine worldwide. That's just logical, and it's changing too fast for the plants to evolve adaptations to the rapidly changing growing conditions. It's easy to see that in 10, 20 and 30 years our global food supply situation will therefore be dire indeed. We haven't been at 2 degrees C higher since 130,000 years ago. We haven't been at 4 degrees C higher since 5 million years ago (!) United Nations IPCC science says that we will have 3 degrees higher by 2050 (!) We humans (body temperature 98.6 degrees F, warm-blooded mammals) have never lived on a planet that warm (!)

@Oldinea Miller Since the year 1500 only 860 species died out. But how do we KNOW this? I'll post my previous comment again in case you missed it, about the numbers. - There are 32,441 threatened species - that we know of - But we know that we don't know even a fraction of all species on Earth. Let me explain. Here is the problem; Current estimates for the number of species on Earth range between 5.3 million and 1 trillion. That‚Äôs a massive degree of uncertainty. It‚Äôs like getting a bank statement that says you have between $5.30 and $1 million in your account. Part of the problem is that we cannot simply count the number of life forms. Many live in inaccessible habitats (such as the deep sea), are too small to see, are hard to find, or live inside other living things. So, instead of counting, scientists try to estimate the total number of species by looking for patterns in biodiversity. Scientists have used a technique based on patterns in the number of species at each level of biological classification to arrive at a prediction of about 8.7 million species. But most estimates of global biodiversity overlook microorganisms such as bacteria because many of these organisms can only be identified to species level by sequencing their DNA. As a result the true diversity of microorganisms may have been underestimated. After compiling and analyzing a database of DNA sequences from 5 million microbe species from 35,000 sites around the world, researchers concluded that there are a staggering 1 trillion species on Earth. It‚Äôs not just the microorganisms that have been overlooked in estimates of global biodiversity. We‚Äôve also ignored the many life forms that live inside other life forms. Most ‚Äì and possibly all ‚Äì insect species are the victim of at least one or more species of parasitic wasp. A more fundamental problem with counting species comes down to a somewhat philosophical issue: biologists do not agree on what the term ‚Äúspecies‚Äù actually means. The well-known biological species concept states that two organisms belong to the same species if they can interbreed and produce fertile offspring. But since this concept relies on mating, it cannot be used to define species of asexual organisms such as many microorganisms as well as some reptiles, birds and fish. It also ignores the fact that many living things we consider separate species can and do interbreed. For example, dogs, coyotes and wolves readily interbreed, yet are usually considered to be separate species. Other popular species definitions rely on how similar individuals are to one another (if it looks like a duck, it is a duck), their shared evolutionary history, or their shared ecological requirements. Yet none of these definitions are entirely satisfactory, and none work for all life forms. There are at least 50 different definitions of a species to choose from. Whether or not a scientist chooses to designate a newly found life form as a new species or not can come down to their philosophical stance about the nature of a species. Our ignorance about the true biodiversity on our planet has real consequence. Each species is a potential treasure trove of solutions to problems including cures for disease, inspirations for new technologies, sources of new materials and providers of key ecosystem services. Yet we are living in an age of mass extinction with reports of catastrophic insect declines, wide-scale depopulation of our oceans and the loss of more than 50% of wildlife within the span of a single human life. Our current rate of biodiversity loss means we are almost certainly losing species faster than we are naming them. We are effectively burning a library without knowing the names or the contents of the books we are losing. So while our estimate of the number of species on the planet remains frustratingly imprecise, the one thing we do know is that we have probably named and described only a tiny percentage of living things. New species are turning up all the time, at a rate of roughly 18,000 species each year. For example, researchers in Los Angeles found 30 new species of scuttle fly living in urban parks, while researchers also in the US discovered more than 1,400 new species of bacteria living in the belly buttons of university students. Even if we take the more conservative estimate of 8.7 million species of life on Earth, then we have only described and named about 25% of life forms on the planet. If the 1 trillion figure is correct, then we have done an abysmally poor job, with 99.99% of species still awaiting description. It‚Äôs clear our planet is absolutely teeming with life, even if we cannot yet put a number to the multitudes. The question now is how much of that awe-inspiring diversity we choose to save.

Most ‚Äì and possibly all ‚Äì insect species are the victim of at least one or more species of parasitic wasp. A more fundamental problem with counting species comes down to a somewhat philosophical issue: biologists do not agree on what the term ‚Äúspecies‚Äù actually means. The well-known biological species concept states that two organisms belong to the same species if they can interbreed and produce fertile offspring. But since this concept relies on mating, it cannot be used to define species of asexual organisms such as many microorganisms as well as some reptiles, birds and fish. It also ignores the fact that many living things we consider separate species can and do interbreed. For example, dogs, coyotes and wolves readily interbreed, yet are usually considered to be separate species. Other popular species definitions rely on how similar individuals are to one another (if it looks like a duck, it is a duck), their shared evolutionary history, or their shared ecological requirements. Yet none of these definitions are entirely satisfactory, and none work for all life forms. There are at least 50 different definitions of a species to choose from. Whether or not a scientist chooses to designate a newly found life form as a new species or not can come down to their philosophical stance about the nature of a species. Our ignorance about the true biodiversity on our planet has real consequence. Each species is a potential treasure trove of solutions to problems including cures for disease, inspirations for new technologies, sources of new materials and providers of key ecosystem services. Yet we are living in an age of mass extinction with reports of catastrophic insect declines, wide-scale depopulation of our oceans and the loss of more than 50% of wildlife within the span of a single human life. Our current rate of biodiversity loss means we are almost certainly losing species faster than we are naming them. We are effectively burning a library without knowing the names or the contents of the books we are losing. So while our estimate of the number of species on the planet remains frustratingly imprecise, the one thing we do know is that we have probably named and described only a tiny percentage of living things. New species are turning up all the time, at a rate of roughly 18,000 species each year. For example, researchers in Los Angeles found 30 new species of scuttle fly living in urban parks, while researchers also in the US discovered more than 1,400 new species of bacteria living in the belly buttons of university students. Even if we take the more conservative estimate of 8.7 million species of life on Earth, then we have only described and named about 25% of life forms on the planet. If the 1 trillion figure is correct, then we have done an abysmally poor job, with 99.99% of species still awaiting description. It‚Äôs clear our planet is absolutely teeming with life, even if we cannot yet put a number to the multitudes. The question now is how much of that awe-inspiring diversity we choose to save.
